question: Ben found a note: What is the prime factorisation of 45?
Liam pointed to a paper that said: Which of the following is the prime factorisation of 72?
Which of these prime factorisations gives a value greater than 100?
A card on the table had the number 108. What is the correct prime factorisation of 108?
The prime factors of 48 are 2 × 2 × 2 × 2 × 3. The prime factors of 60 are 2 × 2 × 3 × 5. What is their HCF?
Two numbers have the following prime factors: Number A = 2 × 2 × 3 × 3 × 5, Number B = 3 × 3 × 5 × 7. What is their HCF?
What is the HCF of 12 and 18 using prime factorisation?
Liam looked at a box labeled 30 and 45. What is the HCF of 30 and 45 using prime factorisation?
Which pair of numbers has the HCF equal to the product of two prime numbers?
The HCF of two numbers is 9. One number is 27. Which of the following could be the other number?
Which of these sets of prime factors give the lowest HCF?
